original_prompt: In this task, you are given a tuple, comprising Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether, as a result of the Head, PersonY or others will want what is mentioned in the Tail or not. In this task, wanting is a postcondition desire on the part of PersonY and others, respectively. For example, as a result of PersonX giving PersonY gifts, PersonY may want to open the gift. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.
generated_prompts: In this task, you are given a tuple of two short phrases, separated with <sep>. These phrases may involve participants, however the names of specific people have been replaced with generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You need to classify your answer into "Yes" or "No", depending on whether, as a result of the Head event, PersonY or others will want what is mentioned in the Tail or not. This wanting is a postcondition desire on the part of PersonY and others, respectively. Additionally, the phrase may contain "___", which can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

You are given a tuple, separated with <sep>, with a Head and Tail event. The Head and Tail are phrases with generic words (e.g. PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ) instead of specific names. PersonX is always the subject of the event. You must determine whether, as a result of the Head, PersonY or others will want what is mentioned in the Tail or not. The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action. For example, if PersonX gives PersonY gifts, PersonY may want to open the gift. Classify your answers into "Yes" or "No".
